title: Confusing error message when trying expression as pattern

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
### Code

```Rust
const X: i32 = 2;

fn main() {
    match 1 {
        (X-1) => {}
        _ => {}
    }
}
```


### Current output

```Shell
error: expected one of `)`, `,`, `@`, or `|`, found `-`
 --> src/bin/match-test.rs:5:11
  |
5 |         (X-1) => {}
  |           ^
  |           |
  |           expected one of `)`, `,`, `@`, or `|`
  |           help: missing `,`

error[E0308]: mismatched types
 --> src/bin/match-test.rs:5:9
  |
4 |     match 1 {
  |           - this expression has type `{integer}`
5 |         (X-1) => {}
  |         ^^^^^ expected integer, found `(_, _)`
  |
  = note: expected type `{integer}`
            found tuple `(_, _)`
```


### Desired output

```Shell
error: expected one of `)`, `,`, `@`, or `|`, found `-`
 --> src/bin/match-test.rs:5:11
  |
5 |         (X-1) => {}
  |           ^
  |           |
  |           expected one of `)`, `,`, `@`, or `|`
  |           help: missing `,`
```


### Rationale and extra context

Maybe there is an easy explanation but I was confused why a tuple type is inferred when trying to use `X-1` as a pattern, but not for `X+1`.

### Other cases

```Rust
For X+1, we just get the error that an arithmetic expression cannot be a pattern.

error: expected one of `)`, `,`, `@`, or `|`, found `+`
 --> src/bin/match-test.rs:5:11
  |
5 |         (X+1) => {}
  |           ^ expected one of `)`, `,`, `@`, or `|`
```


### Anything else?
Using toolchain `stable-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu` with rustc `rustc 1.69.0 (84c898d65 2023-04-16)`
